headline: Senior QA Automation Engineer | Typescript, Javascript, Java | Playwright, WebdriverIO, Selenium, Appium | Blockchain
about:
As a Software Development Engineer in Test (SDET) with a passion for creating high-quality and reliable products, I bring a set of skills with a strong background in software engineering and testing.
I have extensive experience in designing and implementing automation frameworks from scratch, developing and executing test plans, and identifying and debugging issues in software systems. I am always eager to learn new technologies and methodologies to improve my craft. 
My ultimate goal is to help companies deliver software that meets and exceeds customer expectations.

Main aptitudes:
Automated testing: Playwright · Webdriver IO · Selenium · Mocha · Chai · Appium · Cucumber · TestNG · Saucelabs · Browserstack
Programming languages: Typescript · Javascript · Java · Scripting
APIs testing: Postman · Jmeter · Rest-assured · SoapUI
Databases: PostgreSQL · MongoDB
Relesase and CI: Jenkins · Docker · Kubernetes · Gitflow
topSkills: Playwright • TypeScript • WebdriverIO • JavaScript • API Automation

experience.description:
Develop and maintain automated testing frameworks to validate the functionality,
performance, and reliability of our software applications. Collaborate with the development team to understand application features, user stories, and acceptance criteria to create automated test cases.
Integrate automated tests into the CI/CD pipeline to support continuous delivery and
deployment. Execute automated test cases, analyze results, and report testing status to the Tech Lead and relevant stakeholders. Identify, log, and track defects, and work with the development team to facilitate issue resolution.

Led the creation and execution of automated test cases for web apps using WebdriverIO, Mocha, Chai, Javascript, SauceLabs on a cross-browser environment. Created and optimized existing test scripts and increased overall test coverage. Implemented a full automation testing strategy aligned with Agile and DevOps practices.

Specialized in designing and executing automated tests for web, api and mobile applications using Selenium, Appium and Jmeter. Streamlined testing processes by automating repetitive tasks, reducing manual testing efforts. Delivered high-quality results by integrating test automation into Agile workflows and CI/CD pipelines.

Built and maintained automated tests for functional, regression, and smoke tests, using industry-standard tools such as Selenium WebDriver and java. Created and managed automation frameworks, integrating them with TestRail and Bamboo for seamless test execution within a CI/CD pipeline. Collaborated with developers to enhance test coverage and identify defects early in the development lifecycle.

• Applications design and plotter management.
• Design and production area responsible.
• Attention Sales Department.
• Signaling in Hospitals, Clinics, Hotels, Factories, Shops and Transports.
• Support systems and computer network.
• Migration management system.

receivedRecommendations.givenByHeadline: Senior Software Engineer at Leaf Group
receivedRecommendations.givenAt: November 29, 2023, Ani worked with Leandro on the same team
receivedRecommendations.description:
I have had the pleasure of working closely with Leandro  on the same team for several years at Leaf Group (later reamed to World of Good Brands). As an SDET Engineer, Leandro played a crucial role in ensuring the quality and reliability of our CMS application. His automation tests helped things sail smoothly and he was catching bugs before they became headaches on production. 

Leandro is also a reliable team player, very collaborative and always has a great attitude. Working with him was not just productive but also genuinely enjoyable.

Leandro is an awesome SDET engineer, and I have no doubt he'll bring excellence to any team.

receivedRecommendations.givenByHeadline: reconnaissance Software Architect
receivedRecommendations.givenAt: March 21, 2018, Miguel managed Leandro directly
receivedRecommendations.description: I've been lucky enough to have Leandro on my team not only in one company, but on two. During both experiences, I couldn't have asked for a better teammate. Leandro's technical knowledge is a solid as they come. His code understanding is equal to a developers (Which is a rare thing to see on a QA person), I've seen him create automation frameworks from scratch (both front and back end), and also maintain, expand and enhance them. He's the kind of person that you know for a fact when you hand him a job, it will be returned done. No excuses, no compromises, he simply delivers what needs to be done, whether that is a highly technical task, or simply executing whatever needs to be done (like manual testing). On top of that, I'll be hard pressed to name a better person than him; He's always willing to assist, train, and basically help anybody inside (or outside) the team. Leandro is without a shadow of a doubt a winning asset for any serious team. If I could clone him, I'd have the best QA team ever.

receivedRecommendations.givenByHeadline: Technical Architect Director at MuleSoft
receivedRecommendations.givenAt: July 3, 2015, Gastón and Leandro studied together
receivedRecommendations.description: I had the pleasant experience of sharing my years of study at the university with Leandro, and if I had to define him in skills, I would choose efficiency, analytical capacity and fellowship. Definitely a reliable person and willing to help others.

receivedRecommendations.givenByHeadline: Staff Engineer at MercadoLibre
receivedRecommendations.givenAt: May 23, 2012, Diego worked with Leandro on the same team
receivedRecommendations.description: During the time I have worked with Leandro, he has proven to be extremely professional and a reliable and committed colleague. Not only has Leandro shown a lot of confidence when tackling new projects but also when learning new tools and technologies. He is proactive and he is always willing to help his co-workers with any problem they may have.

headline: #researcher #consultant #trainer #writer #social innovation #creativity #STEAM education #sustainability
about:
Researcher, trainer, consultant, writer & speaker. Passionate about learning, innovation and social change towards sustainability. Deeply interested in developing projects to foster social innovation & creativity and entrepreneurial capabilities...

Look forward to linking with you!

experience.position: Expert participating in the evaluation of HORIZON EUROPE projects

experience.description:
I participated in evaluation activities or as member of advisory boards as an independent expert in social innovation and related topics such as social innnovation labs (living-labs, urban labs), multi-stakeholder cross-sectoral innovation and smart specialization.
- Expert at the Expert Workshop of the European project 'ICT-Enabled Social Innovation in Support to the Implementation of the EU Social Investment Package'. Joint Research Centre, Institute for Prospective Technological Studies (JRC-IPTS) & DG Employment, Social Affairs and Inclusion, Brussels, Belgium. February 2015 
- Invited to the Workshop on Horizontal Issues for the European Innovation Partnership on Active Health and Quality of Life. European Commission, 24-25th October 2011

Expert evaluator. Evaluation committee for the USA and Canada La Caixa Foundation Scholarship Programme for post-graduate students. Barcelona, Spain. July 2015.

Advisor to the Vice-Direction of European Convergence and Quality. Faculty of Informatics, Polytechnic University of Madrid, Spain, 2008-2010. Curricular development, design and planning of e-PIEC (digital portfolio on soft competences assessment) and academic staff training. 

Curricular development, coordination and management of the committee to planning the Master on Science and Technology Management between the Technological Institute of Costa Rica, the Institute of Innovation and Knowledge Management (CSIC-UPV) and the  Organization of Ibero-American States. 2009-2010. 

Advisor of the expert group. Curricular reform in science education. Government Agency of Education. Córdoba, Argentina, 2008.

Advisor. Subdirection of European Convergence, School of Design Engineering, UPV. Support to adapt seven engineering degrees in different specialties to the European Higher Education Area. Coordination of 40 internship students’ grants, design of competency-maps & assessment indicators. 2004 to 2006 

Students's contest organization. Theme: Actors' perceptions about the convergence process towards the European Higher Education Area. 2006

experience.location: Various countries (Argentina, Spain, Portugal, Costa Rica)
experience.description:
Plenary Speaker. ‘Expanding innovation boundaries: tech-social innovations and hybrid innovations’. VIII International Conference on Science, technology and Society. 10th January 2019, Universidade NOVA de Lisboa, Portugal. 

Speaker. Cooperation between social economy enterprises and traditional enterprises. Conference Creating Value Together: Towards joint business opportunities with social economy and traditional enterprises. European Commission. EASME/COSME (EC), 3-4 July 2018 

Social innovations and co-creation of value. Organized by WomenCEO. CEU San Pablo. Valencia. 25 April 2018

‘Creativity & design thinking for social innovation’. FabLab Burgos. University of Burgos. 27th April 2018. 

Plenary speaker. ‘Blue innovation: A new sustainability roadmap?’ VII International Congress of Technology Science and Society. Valencia, Spain, 20th October 2017

Plenary speaker. ‘Shaken, but not stirred: Sixty years defining social innovation’. V International Congress on Social Sciences. Univ. Rey Juan Carlos. Madrid, Spain, 12-14 July 2017 

Plenary speaker. 'The future of Engineering degrees: challenges and opportunities’. 41 International Book Fair. Buenos Aires, Argentina, 2015 

Science education for social innovation. Invited by the Education Government of Cordoba, Argentina. 2015

‘Creativity, innovation and entrepreneurship for social inclusion’. Workshop on Innovation and Territorial Development, Benedita, Portugal, 2013 

Educating for action: synergy between education, social innovation and sustainable development. Conference. National University of Córdoba. Argentina. 2012.
 
Plenary speaker. ‘Quo vadis educ-action?’. 7th International Conference on Interdisciplinary Social Sciences, Barcelona, Spain. 2012 

'Ecology, peace and sustainability'. Conference. Valencia, Spain. 2011

'Building Cultures of peace through social networks and community of practice'. Summer School Education, Human Rights and Citizenship, University of Santiago de Compostela. 2009
Volunteer activity to mentor girls in STEM careers with focus on soft skills as well as creativity, entrepreneurial and innovation capabilities.
Participation in a network to improve the motivation & students's engagement in STEM education

experience.companyName: European Innovation Council and SMEs Executive Agency (EISMEA)
experience.description: Expert Evaluator in the field of social economy, and social economy industrial ecosystems

experience.companyName: EIT - European Institute of Innovation and Technology
experience.description: Evaluation of  the strategic implementation, outcomes, and impact of a pportfolio with 48 projects (KAVAs) in various Knowledge and Innovation Communities (KIC) areas

experience.position: Lecturer at Posgraduate program in STEAM education
experience.companyName: Instituto Global de Altos Estudios en Ciencias Sociales (IGLOBAL)
experience.description:
Lecturer of two Courses: Design thinking and Gamification in STEAM education. 
Trained two cohorts with 127 and 115 teachers of different backgrounds and education levels

experience.position: Lecturer of Creativity & Design Thinking. STEAM Postgraduate Program
experience.description:
Specialist degree on STEAM education (Science, Technology, Engineering, Art & Mathematics), on-line & blended courses.
The innovative program (FIVE Editions!) involves robotics, computational thinking & coding (scratch, microbit, lego) 
My module includes creativity, emphaty tools for learning, mind and concept mapping, design thinking using 3D printers (e.g., tinkercad) and gamification

experience.position: Independent Expert Evaluator. 6i Dirs project Call 2021, Towards the Circular Economy

experience.companyName: COST Association - European Cooperation in Science and Technology
Center for Teacher Training and Educational Innovation (CEFIRE)
experience.description: Gamification in STEAM higher education. Course for in-service and pre-service teachers

experience.companyName: EASME COSME Social Business Initiative (SBI) project (cooperation between social economy & business)
experience.description:
As associated research consultant with Technopolisgroup I developed the analytical framework to map cooperation relationships between social economy entities and for-profit firms, including case studies of sharing and circular economy. 
The project comprises the study of several dimensions of cooperation, such as motives, drivers and barriers, cooperation types, role of intermediaries, value generated, social innovations and social impact. 
Also the analysis and development of indicators of competitive clusters, co-creation in hybrid value chains, social intrapreneurship, incubation and social-startups, number of social "extra-preneurs" in all countries covered (including outside EU28), investment, public and private procurement, sponsorship, emergent forms of CSR and CSI, competence voluntary work and pro bono investments, shared methods of management, and benchmarking with the US, Canada, Brazil and SouthKorea.

projects.title: ‘Social innovation futures: beyond policy panacea and conceptual ambiguity’, European Forum for Studies of Policies for Research and Innovation (EU-spri Forum)
projects.description: Social innovation is once more an increasingly popular notion circulating as an apparent means to solve the Grand Challenges of the 21st Century.  But this common-sense idea of social innovation is based on a quasi-concept, where processes of innovation are absent.  To restore some academic rigour to this important concept, we argue more attention need be paid to these innovation processes in social innovation, and that there is value in using innovation concepts drawn from other areas of innovation studies (disruptive innovation, innovation systems, institutional innovation and socio-technical transitions) in highlighting how small-scale social experiments can ultimately lead to the solution of pressing societal problems.  Through a subtle critique of the current policy conception of social innovation, we attempt to provide better insights into social innovation processes and ultimately to lead to better support frameworks and interventions for promoting solutions to these Grand Challenges.

publications.title: The nature and variety of innovation
publications.publishedAt: International Journal of Innovation Studies · Oct 1, 2018
publications.description:
What is our current understanding of innovation and how many types of innovation do we
know? Broadly, innovation landscapes are characterized by well-established categories, such
as product, process, organizational, and marketing innovation, explained and theorized in terms
of their links with technological innovation. However global challenges and changes in the
structure of knowledge production, have led to diverse innovations, and recognizing and classifying
such innovations is more complex, fragmented, and geographically dispersed than ever
before. The progressive incorporation of hidden and non-technological innovations, together
with the emergence of the fourth industrial revolution, are contributing to a better understanding
of innovation and opportunities for its measurement. This paper provides an overview of the most salient types of innovation in recent decades, enabling both researchers and practitioners to navigate the complex web of innovation definitions and typologies. Innovation studies face the challenge of
finding a comprehensive and inclusive definition that captures the significance of innovation,
and overcoming the terminological ‘Babel'ization and increased fragmentation of the field of
innovation research.

publications.title: 'Shaken, but not stirred’: Sixty years of defining social innovation
publications.publishedAt: Technological Forecasting and Social Change · Mar 1, 2017
publications.description: This paper examines the evolution in the conceptualization of Social Innovation (SI) with a view to elucidating the multiplication of uses of the term over the last half century. We performed a comprehensive and systematic literature review extracting 252 definitions of SI through a search of 2,339 documents comprising academic papers, books and book chapters, together research and policy reports. To guide the inductive analysis of pluri-vocal discourses we assume innovation to be a learning-based process involving actors’ interactions and social practices. We apply mixed qualitative methodologies, combining content analysis based on an interpretivist ontology with cognitive mapping techniques. Our findings show that SI was introduced as an analytical concept by incipient academic communities and has spread in the last decades as a normative concept fuelled by development and innovation policies. SI is defined by a set of common core elements underpinning three different and interrelated discursive ‘areas’: processes of social change, sustainable development and the services sector. We point to some policy implications and a number of promising avenues for research towards the advancement of a broader socio-technical theory of innovation.

publications.title: Dynamic interactions between university-industry knowledge transfer channels: A case study of the most highly cited academic patent. Co-authored with Joaquín M. Azagra-Caro, David Barberá-Tomás & Elena M. Tur.
publications.publishedAt: Research Policy · Dec 1, 2016
publications.description: This paper examines the succession of formal and informal channels of university-industry knowledge transfer, and the local economic impact of their dynamic interaction. To do so, we investigate a highly cited university patent over an extended period of time through a case study methodology. Our work provides three fundamental insights. First, local economic impact can be achieved only after a complex, temporally unfolding sequence of interactions between formal and informal channels of knowledge transfer. Second, in the course of this dynamic interaction, knowledge generated during formal transfer activities may be transferred via informal channels. Third, the method developed can provide information on the variety of knowledge transfer channels related to highly cited patents.

publications.title: Challenges to Firms' Collaborative Innovation Facing the Innovation Babel Tower
publications.publishedAt: Handbook of Research on Driving Competitive Advantage through Sustainable, Lean, and Disruptive Innovation (IGI Global, USA) · Jan 1, 2016
publications.description: Access to different internal and external knowledge sources and learning constitute key dimensions of firms' innovation capabilities to the maintenance of their competitive advantage. The increasing emergence of new modes of innovation involving a diversity of multi-stakeholder collaborations between industry, business, academy and civil society represents a challenge not only to firms' collaborative behaviour but the way to organize, integrate and manage new innovative capabilities. In this context this chapter: a) explores and characterizes the different types of innovation ‘underlying' in the current Innovation Tower of Babel and its implications to the firms' cooperative innovation strategy and knowledge governance and b) provides examples of new target organization models, such as living labs and other ‘innovation labs' where these types of innovations are being developed.

publications.title: Social innovation futures: beyond policy panacea and conceptual ambiguity
publications.publishedAt: Working Paper for the TIK Group Series · Jan 1, 2015
publications.description: Social innovation is once more an increasingly popular notion circulating as an apparent means to solve the Grand Challenges of the 21st Century. But this common-sense idea of social innovation is based on a quasi-concept, where processes of innovation are absent. To restore some academic rigour to this important concept, we argue more attention need be paid to these innovation processes in social innovation, and that there is value in using innovation concepts drawn from other areas of innovation studies (disruptive innovation, innovation systems, institutional innovation and socio-technical transitions) in highlighting how small-scale social experiments can ultimately lead to the solution of pressing societal problems. Through a subtle critique of the current policy conception of social innovation, it is possible for the field of Innovation Studies in general to help provide better insights into social innovation processes and ultimately to lead to better support frameworks and interventions for promoting solutions to these Grand Challenges.

publications.title: Disentangling competences: Interrelationships on creativity, innovation and entrepreneurship
publications.publishedAt: Thinking Skills & Creativity · Jan 1, 2015
publications.description: Creativity, innovation and entrepreneurship are recognized as crucial to foster an entrepreneurial culture, but their relationships from the competence-based approach aren’t yet sufficiently understood. This paper contributes to the ongoing debate on the nature of entrepreneurial competences critically analyzing the theoretical underpinnings to such interrelationships. Our literature review informs that the focus, core assumptions and educational approaches to entrepreneurial competences and the role of creativity and innovation may vary substantially depending on which educational paradigm is considered (educating ‘for’, ‘about’ and ‘through’ entrepreneurship). We present arguments on the adequacy of Social Cognitive Theory and Social Constructivism to explain the development of Creativity, Innovation and Entrepreneurship (CIE) as a meta-competence. In this framework we undertake a preliminary empirical approximation to the area under study exploring how engineering students from two different socio-cultural contexts, Spain and USA, perceive CIE relationships and to what extent they believe they are developed by the education system. Empirical findings show that most students see themselves as creative people and consider that creativity is strongly related to innovation and entrepreneurship, being more convinced American than Spanish students on the relevance of creativity among entrepreneurs’ competences. Moreover, their perceptions contrast with the role assigned to education, where they consider that creativity is still a pending subject in engineering education.

publications.title: Book chapter: Motives for International Inter-Firm Cooperation on R&D and Innovation: Literature Overview and Recent Trends
publications.publishedAt: IGI Global. Handbook Quality Innovation: Knowledge Theory and Practices. Editors: Latif Al-Hakim (University of Southern Queensland, Australia) & Chen Jin (Zhejiang University, China) · Jan 1, 2014

publications.title: Generation and Diffusion of Innovations in a District Innovation System: The Case of Ink-Jet Printing
publications.publishedAt: Journal of Technology Management & Innovation · Jan 1, 2014
publications.description: This paper provides an in-depth case study of the ink-jet printing (IJP) technology that emerged from the ceramic industry in a Spanish region (Castellon) in the first decade of 2000. We propose an analytical framework that combines the theoretical perspectives of Industrial Districts and Innovation Systems, and exploit a qualitative methodology that includes information from patent and scientific article databases and 21 in-depth interviews. Our results show that IJP is a major innovation that breaks with the tradition of machinery innovations in this industry in Spain. Micro-level evidences show the complex external and internal relationships in the sharing of knowledge and innovation process, being the role of internal ties, trust, secrecy and strong in-house R&D strategies determinants of the IJP innovation.

publications.title: How empowering is social innovation? Identifying barriers to participation in community-driven innovation
publications.publishedAt: NESTA. UK. London · Dec 17, 2013
publications.description: Empowerment and community participation have been recognized as means and outcomes of social innovations. In the last decade, these ideas have been reflected in the growing movement of formal and informal ‘Living Labs’ (LLs). They are emerging as a new model of organizing col-laborative innovation processes with the participation of business, government and civil actors. LLs constitute knowledge hubs that are opening a contested terrain in which habitual distinctions between ‘producers’ and ‘users’ of knowledge are increasingly blurred. This chapter investigates actors’ perceptions about power and knowledge relationships in a Living Lab context. We present an in-depth study case, complemented with information of 120 Living Labs obtained from the European Network of Living Labs (ENoLL) website and other secondary sources. Our ﬁndings show that participation and empowerment are constrained by relational, structural and cultural bar-riers. Understanding power and knowledge dynamics in innovation processes entails broadening our analytical and practical lens to consider knowledge asymmetries and struggles between ‘instru-mental’ and ‘transformative’ rationalities. Findings suggest that the governance of LLs and similar models of collaborative innovation needs to consider how the power dynamics of a given context can enable or constrain the empowerment of people as ‘users’ and ‘co-creators’ of knowledge

publications.title: Motives for international cooperation on R&D and innovation: empirical evidence from Argentinean and Spanish firms
publications.publishedAt: International Journal of Technology Management · Jul 1, 2013
publications.description:
This paper focuses on the strategic motives and firm characteristics that influence cooperation for R&D and innovation among Argentinean and Spanish firms. On the basis of a review of different theoretical perspectives we propose and apply a taxonomy of motives for inter-firm technological
cooperation. We combined quantitative and qualitative methodologies, developing a database of 540 innovative firms and conducting a survey that obtained evidence from 104 of these firms, supplemented by information gathered from 19 in-depth interviews. Our results show that technological cooperation is not easy to achieve and determined by a complex interplay of
intentions and practical opportunities. The lack of convergence in the motives for cooperation creates un-favourable conditions and affects negatively the initiation of the cooperation processes. These differences together with asymmetries in access to funding are important obstacles to cooperation with implications in the administration of national policy incentives and its
regulation mechanisms.

publications.title: Fostering Quality of Life through Social Innovation: A Living Lab Methodology Study Case
publications.publishedAt: Review of Policy Research Volume 29, Number 6:672-692. · Nov 15, 2012
publications.description: Participative processes and citizens’ empowerment are considered crucial aspects of social innovation (SI), involving collaborative activities between the private, public, and third sectors. This article discusses the principal trends in the literature on the concept of SI, its aims and differential characteristics related to the identification of people’s needs, citizen participation processes, and improved quality of life. We present an exploratory case study of SI focusing on the gap between elderly people’s needs and the generation of business opportunities, using a living lab (LL) methodology for collaborative placed-based innovation. Our results suggest that LLs are a useful instrument to detect community needs and improve local development and support and integrate technological and social innovations in policies and local governance processes.

publications.title: International co-operation between firms on Innovation and R&D: Empirical evidence from Argentina and Spain
publications.publishedAt: Journal of Technology Management & Innovation Vol. 6(3):126-147. · Jan 1, 2011
publications.description: This paper examines co-operative innovation and Research and Development (R&D) behaviour between Argentine and Spanish firms. Based on theoretical perspectives from the literature, we present empirical evidence obtained from 104 firms of patterns of cooperation in several processes and out-puts, highlighting firm characteristics, the motives of the collaborating parties, types of partners, R&D and innovation activities, leadership, and obstacles to cooperation. Our results reveal that the determinants of success differ considerably among countries depending on the sector, the firm specific characteristics and funding.These differences have important implications for public policy and instruments to support R&D and innovation activities.

publications.title: Achieving competence-based curriculum in Engineering Education in Spain
publications.publishedAt: Proceedings of the IEEE. USA. Vol. 97, No. 10:1727–1736 · Oct 1, 2009
publications.description: The fact of placing competences and outcomes learning at the heart of the academic activity means overhauling the curricular architecture of higher education in Europe. Some universities have undergone important transformations moving toward a competence-based learning environment, while others maintain traditional curriculum packaged formats. In the realm of the European Higher Education Area, this paper examines the use of competence-based initiatives in curricular development for engineering degrees with special focus to the Spanish case. Although the concept of competence and competence-based learning has a long history in education and training research, these terms are still very diffuse and demand a clear conceptualization. In the first part of this paper, we provide a conceptual overview and a critical reflection of competences as implemented in a wide range of settings, including its origins, key concepts, and definitions. Next, we discuss the purposes, principles, pitfalls, and processes that enable defining a map of competences within engineering education. Lastly, we present a pilot project involving curriculum development and faculty enhancement within a competence-based learning initiative in electronic engineering.

experience.companyName: EASME COSME Social Business Initiative (SBI) project (cooperation between social economy & business)
experience.description:
As associated research consultant with Technopolisgroup I developed the analytical framework to map cooperation relationships between social economy entities and for-profit firms, including case studies of sharing and circular economy. 
The project comprises the study of several dimensions of cooperation, such as motives, drivers and barriers, cooperation types, role of intermediaries, value generated, social innovations and social impact. 
Also the analysis and development of indicators of competitive clusters, co-creation in hybrid value chains, social intrapreneurship, incubation and social-startups, number of social "extra-preneurs" in all countries covered (including outside EU28), investment, public and private procurement, sponsorship, emergent forms of CSR and CSI, competence voluntary work and pro bono investments, shared methods of management, and benchmarking with the US, Canada, Brazil and SouthKorea.

projects.title: ‘Social innovation futures: beyond policy panacea and conceptual ambiguity’, European Forum for Studies of Policies for Research and Innovation (EU-spri Forum)
projects.description: Social innovation is once more an increasingly popular notion circulating as an apparent means to solve the Grand Challenges of the 21st Century.  But this common-sense idea of social innovation is based on a quasi-concept, where processes of innovation are absent.  To restore some academic rigour to this important concept, we argue more attention need be paid to these innovation processes in social innovation, and that there is value in using innovation concepts drawn from other areas of innovation studies (disruptive innovation, innovation systems, institutional innovation and socio-technical transitions) in highlighting how small-scale social experiments can ultimately lead to the solution of pressing societal problems.  Through a subtle critique of the current policy conception of social innovation, we attempt to provide better insights into social innovation processes and ultimately to lead to better support frameworks and interventions for promoting solutions to these Grand Challenges.

publications.title: The nature and variety of innovation
publications.publishedAt: International Journal of Innovation Studies · Oct 1, 2018
publications.description:
What is our current understanding of innovation and how many types of innovation do we
know? Broadly, innovation landscapes are characterized by well-established categories, such
as product, process, organizational, and marketing innovation, explained and theorized in terms
of their links with technological innovation. However global challenges and changes in the
structure of knowledge production, have led to diverse innovations, and recognizing and classifying
such innovations is more complex, fragmented, and geographically dispersed than ever
before. The progressive incorporation of hidden and non-technological innovations, together
with the emergence of the fourth industrial revolution, are contributing to a better understanding
of innovation and opportunities for its measurement. This paper provides an overview of the most salient types of innovation in recent decades, enabling both researchers and practitioners to navigate the complex web of innovation definitions and typologies. Innovation studies face the challenge of
finding a comprehensive and inclusive definition that captures the significance of innovation,
and overcoming the terminological ‘Babel'ization and increased fragmentation of the field of
innovation research.

publications.title: 'Shaken, but not stirred’: Sixty years of defining social innovation
publications.publishedAt: Technological Forecasting and Social Change · Mar 1, 2017
publications.description: This paper examines the evolution in the conceptualization of Social Innovation (SI) with a view to elucidating the multiplication of uses of the term over the last half century. We performed a comprehensive and systematic literature review extracting 252 definitions of SI through a search of 2,339 documents comprising academic papers, books and book chapters, together research and policy reports. To guide the inductive analysis of pluri-vocal discourses we assume innovation to be a learning-based process involving actors’ interactions and social practices. We apply mixed qualitative methodologies, combining content analysis based on an interpretivist ontology with cognitive mapping techniques. Our findings show that SI was introduced as an analytical concept by incipient academic communities and has spread in the last decades as a normative concept fuelled by development and innovation policies. SI is defined by a set of common core elements underpinning three different and interrelated discursive ‘areas’: processes of social change, sustainable development and the services sector. We point to some policy implications and a number of promising avenues for research towards the advancement of a broader socio-technical theory of innovation.

publications.title: Dynamic interactions between university-industry knowledge transfer channels: A case study of the most highly cited academic patent. Co-authored with Joaquín M. Azagra-Caro, David Barberá-Tomás & Elena M. Tur.
publications.publishedAt: Research Policy · Dec 1, 2016
publications.description: This paper examines the succession of formal and informal channels of university-industry knowledge transfer, and the local economic impact of their dynamic interaction. To do so, we investigate a highly cited university patent over an extended period of time through a case study methodology. Our work provides three fundamental insights. First, local economic impact can be achieved only after a complex, temporally unfolding sequence of interactions between formal and informal channels of knowledge transfer. Second, in the course of this dynamic interaction, knowledge generated during formal transfer activities may be transferred via informal channels. Third, the method developed can provide information on the variety of knowledge transfer channels related to highly cited patents.

publications.title: Challenges to Firms' Collaborative Innovation Facing the Innovation Babel Tower
publications.publishedAt: Handbook of Research on Driving Competitive Advantage through Sustainable, Lean, and Disruptive Innovation (IGI Global, USA) · Jan 1, 2016
publications.description: Access to different internal and external knowledge sources and learning constitute key dimensions of firms' innovation capabilities to the maintenance of their competitive advantage. The increasing emergence of new modes of innovation involving a diversity of multi-stakeholder collaborations between industry, business, academy and civil society represents a challenge not only to firms' collaborative behaviour but the way to organize, integrate and manage new innovative capabilities. In this context this chapter: a) explores and characterizes the different types of innovation ‘underlying' in the current Innovation Tower of Babel and its implications to the firms' cooperative innovation strategy and knowledge governance and b) provides examples of new target organization models, such as living labs and other ‘innovation labs' where these types of innovations are being developed.

publications.publishedAt: Working Paper for the TIK Group Series · Jan 1, 2015
publications.description: Social innovation is once more an increasingly popular notion circulating as an apparent means to solve the Grand Challenges of the 21st Century. But this common-sense idea of social innovation is based on a quasi-concept, where processes of innovation are absent. To restore some academic rigour to this important concept, we argue more attention need be paid to these innovation processes in social innovation, and that there is value in using innovation concepts drawn from other areas of innovation studies (disruptive innovation, innovation systems, institutional innovation and socio-technical transitions) in highlighting how small-scale social experiments can ultimately lead to the solution of pressing societal problems. Through a subtle critique of the current policy conception of social innovation, it is possible for the field of Innovation Studies in general to help provide better insights into social innovation processes and ultimately to lead to better support frameworks and interventions for promoting solutions to these Grand Challenges.

publications.title: Disentangling competences: Interrelationships on creativity, innovation and entrepreneurship
publications.publishedAt: Thinking Skills & Creativity · Jan 1, 2015
publications.description: Creativity, innovation and entrepreneurship are recognized as crucial to foster an entrepreneurial culture, but their relationships from the competence-based approach aren’t yet sufficiently understood. This paper contributes to the ongoing debate on the nature of entrepreneurial competences critically analyzing the theoretical underpinnings to such interrelationships. Our literature review informs that the focus, core assumptions and educational approaches to entrepreneurial competences and the role of creativity and innovation may vary substantially depending on which educational paradigm is considered (educating ‘for’, ‘about’ and ‘through’ entrepreneurship). We present arguments on the adequacy of Social Cognitive Theory and Social Constructivism to explain the development of Creativity, Innovation and Entrepreneurship (CIE) as a meta-competence. In this framework we undertake a preliminary empirical approximation to the area under study exploring how engineering students from two different socio-cultural contexts, Spain and USA, perceive CIE relationships and to what extent they believe they are developed by the education system. Empirical findings show that most students see themselves as creative people and consider that creativity is strongly related to innovation and entrepreneurship, being more convinced American than Spanish students on the relevance of creativity among entrepreneurs’ competences. Moreover, their perceptions contrast with the role assigned to education, where they consider that creativity is still a pending subject in engineering education.

publications.title: Book chapter: Motives for International Inter-Firm Cooperation on R&D and Innovation: Literature Overview and Recent Trends
publications.publishedAt: IGI Global. Handbook Quality Innovation: Knowledge Theory and Practices. Editors: Latif Al-Hakim (University of Southern Queensland, Australia) & Chen Jin (Zhejiang University, China) · Jan 1, 2014

publications.title: Generation and Diffusion of Innovations in a District Innovation System: The Case of Ink-Jet Printing
publications.publishedAt: Journal of Technology Management & Innovation · Jan 1, 2014
publications.description: This paper provides an in-depth case study of the ink-jet printing (IJP) technology that emerged from the ceramic industry in a Spanish region (Castellon) in the first decade of 2000. We propose an analytical framework that combines the theoretical perspectives of Industrial Districts and Innovation Systems, and exploit a qualitative methodology that includes information from patent and scientific article databases and 21 in-depth interviews. Our results show that IJP is a major innovation that breaks with the tradition of machinery innovations in this industry in Spain. Micro-level evidences show the complex external and internal relationships in the sharing of knowledge and innovation process, being the role of internal ties, trust, secrecy and strong in-house R&D strategies determinants of the IJP innovation.

publications.title: How empowering is social innovation? Identifying barriers to participation in community-driven innovation
publications.publishedAt: NESTA. UK. London · Dec 17, 2013
publications.description: Empowerment and community participation have been recognized as means and outcomes of social innovations. In the last decade, these ideas have been reflected in the growing movement of formal and informal ‘Living Labs’ (LLs). They are emerging as a new model of organizing col-laborative innovation processes with the participation of business, government and civil actors. LLs constitute knowledge hubs that are opening a contested terrain in which habitual distinctions between ‘producers’ and ‘users’ of knowledge are increasingly blurred. This chapter investigates actors’ perceptions about power and knowledge relationships in a Living Lab context. We present an in-depth study case, complemented with information of 120 Living Labs obtained from the European Network of Living Labs (ENoLL) website and other secondary sources. Our ﬁndings show that participation and empowerment are constrained by relational, structural and cultural bar-riers. Understanding power and knowledge dynamics in innovation processes entails broadening our analytical and practical lens to consider knowledge asymmetries and struggles between ‘instru-mental’ and ‘transformative’ rationalities. Findings suggest that the governance of LLs and similar models of collaborative innovation needs to consider how the power dynamics of a given context can enable or constrain the empowerment of people as ‘users’ and ‘co-creators’ of knowledge

publications.title: Motives for international cooperation on R&D and innovation: empirical evidence from Argentinean and Spanish firms
publications.publishedAt: International Journal of Technology Management · Jul 1, 2013
publications.description:
This paper focuses on the strategic motives and firm characteristics that influence cooperation for R&D and innovation among Argentinean and Spanish firms. On the basis of a review of different theoretical perspectives we propose and apply a taxonomy of motives for inter-firm technological
cooperation. We combined quantitative and qualitative methodologies, developing a database of 540 innovative firms and conducting a survey that obtained evidence from 104 of these firms, supplemented by information gathered from 19 in-depth interviews. Our results show that technological cooperation is not easy to achieve and determined by a complex interplay of
intentions and practical opportunities. The lack of convergence in the motives for cooperation creates un-favourable conditions and affects negatively the initiation of the cooperation processes. These differences together with asymmetries in access to funding are important obstacles to cooperation with implications in the administration of national policy incentives and its
regulation mechanisms.

publications.title: Fostering Quality of Life through Social Innovation: A Living Lab Methodology Study Case
publications.publishedAt: Review of Policy Research Volume 29, Number 6:672-692. · Nov 15, 2012
publications.description: Participative processes and citizens’ empowerment are considered crucial aspects of social innovation (SI), involving collaborative activities between the private, public, and third sectors. This article discusses the principal trends in the literature on the concept of SI, its aims and differential characteristics related to the identification of people’s needs, citizen participation processes, and improved quality of life. We present an exploratory case study of SI focusing on the gap between elderly people’s needs and the generation of business opportunities, using a living lab (LL) methodology for collaborative placed-based innovation. Our results suggest that LLs are a useful instrument to detect community needs and improve local development and support and integrate technological and social innovations in policies and local governance processes.

publications.title: Technical Evolution of Ceramic Tile Printing
publications.publishedAt: Journal of Imaging Science and Technology · Jan 1, 2012

publications.title: Improving Organizational Learning with Concept Maps: A Business Case Study
publications.publishedAt: Moon, B.; Hoffman, R. R.; Novak, J. and Cañas, A. (Eds.). Applied Concept Mapping Theory, Techniques, and Case Studies in the Business Applications of Novakian Concept Mapping. Taylor & Francis. · Apr 11, 2011

publications.title: International co-operation between firms on Innovation and R&D: Empirical evidence from Argentina and Spain
publications.publishedAt: Journal of Technology Management & Innovation Vol. 6(3):126-147. · Jan 1, 2011
publications.description: This paper examines co-operative innovation and Research and Development (R&D) behaviour between Argentine and Spanish firms. Based on theoretical perspectives from the literature, we present empirical evidence obtained from 104 firms of patterns of cooperation in several processes and out-puts, highlighting firm characteristics, the motives of the collaborating parties, types of partners, R&D and innovation activities, leadership, and obstacles to cooperation. Our results reveal that the determinants of success differ considerably among countries depending on the sector, the firm specific characteristics and funding.These differences have important implications for public policy and instruments to support R&D and innovation activities.

publications.title: Networks and practice communities for improving motivation and learning in science & technological education. In Current Challenges in basic science education
publications.publishedAt: UNESCO · Apr 10, 2010

publications.title: Achieving competence-based curriculum in Engineering Education in Spain
publications.publishedAt: Proceedings of the IEEE. USA. Vol. 97, No. 10:1727–1736 · Oct 1, 2009
publications.description: The fact of placing competences and outcomes learning at the heart of the academic activity means overhauling the curricular architecture of higher education in Europe. Some universities have undergone important transformations moving toward a competence-based learning environment, while others maintain traditional curriculum packaged formats. In the realm of the European Higher Education Area, this paper examines the use of competence-based initiatives in curricular development for engineering degrees with special focus to the Spanish case. Although the concept of competence and competence-based learning has a long history in education and training research, these terms are still very diffuse and demand a clear conceptualization. In the first part of this paper, we provide a conceptual overview and a critical reflection of competences as implemented in a wide range of settings, including its origins, key concepts, and definitions. Next, we discuss the purposes, principles, pitfalls, and processes that enable defining a map of competences within engineering education. Lastly, we present a pilot project involving curriculum development and faculty enhancement within a competence-based learning initiative in electronic engineering.

headline: TA Ops | HRBP | HR Business Partner | People Ops | Global HR with expertise in high-impact projects and talent strategies for complex international teams
about:
Bachelor’s in Business Administration and Master in Human Resources Business Partner (HRBP). I spent over 4 years of my career as a Global HRBP, providing end-to-end HR support and participating and leading high-impact people projects in markets such as Europe, North America and Asia. Thanks to my extensive experience I developed a solid background in both soft and hard HR areas such as: Reporting, Organizational Structure, KPIs, Stakeholder Management, Performance Management, On/Offboarding, Goal Setting, Negotiation, Employee Engagement, eNPS, Retention/Fidelity. 
My goal is to establish myself and develop my career in HR/People in the European market at a fast-paced organization, playing a key role in building a strong and motivated workforce, working towards a people-centric culture with a problem-solving aptitude and focusing on process improvements led by a growth mindset.
topSkills: Gestión del talento • Trabajo en equipo • Desarrollo de liderazgo • Gestión de proyectos • Comunicación

experience.description:
Single point of contact with HR, providing end-to-end support of the employee's life, for two global teams within Accenture: Labs & Open Innovation. The headcount is 170 people, with locations in countries such as the United States, United Kingdom, Spain, India, France, Ireland, Italy, China, among others. These teams conform a highly complex section within Accenture, working in fields such as Artificial Intelligence, Cybersecurity, Blockchain, Quantum Computing. Acting as an HRBP with such complex profiles represents a great challenge in my career. Daily duties include: 
* Manage specific aspects of HR such as acting as Coach for discussions of performance and compensation process. 
* Strategic partner to senior leads to facilitate decision making with metrics, KPIs and strategic advice.
* Worked in a fast-paced, dynamic environment, managing multiple senior stakeholders and priorities.
* Led projects to improve employee engagement, with a focus on the diversity agenda.
* Providing advice and guidance to individuals based on a strong understanding of their interests, aspirations and business knowledge.
* Ensured compliance with local and international labor laws regarding processes such as leaves, vacation, overtime, in order to remain compliant across regions.
* Ongoing communication with practice leaders to understand the business/practice strategy in order to apply that knowledge to guide employees. In turn, inform leaders of the availability of talent with specific specializations. 
* Assist the employee during the process of connecting them with projects, guiding people to roles where they are considered a "perfect fit". 
* Lead core HR processes such as: employee performance management, talent development, retention/fidelity, engagement, eNPS, Job Families Restructuring, Talent Sourcing Strategy
* Organize and lead employee farewell interviews (offboarding).

headline: Trade Lifecycle Support | Prime Brokerage | JPMorgan Chase & Co

experience.location: Valencia/València, Comunidad Valenciana / Comunitat Valenciana, España
experience.description:
- Key contact throughout the client onboarding process to ensure seamless transition from Sales to BAU
- Coordinating client adoptions, account openings, review of fund offering documentation and legal agreements, internal system setups and project planning
- Project management and coordination of internal functions to onboard new clients (launches and conversions) including Service Delivery, Sales, Legal, Compliance and Technology teams.
- Providing regular status updates to new clients and internal parties. Weekly project calls with stakeholders and project plans maintained to track progress.
- Initial drafting and review of client service agreements
- Collaborating with Legal Department on template management and control
- Managing the internal review process across different product and service lines within the fund administration, depository and other product lines

experience.position: Trade lifecycle | Prime Brokerage | JPMorgan Chase & Co
Senior | International Tax and Transaction Services | Transfer Pricing
experience.description: The core of the position is to test that prices between related parties are made under market conditions (“arm’s length standard”). For this purpose, a work team is coordinated and managed through which the following tasks are carried out: data collection, financial and accounting information management, economic analysis of different industries and their profitability; interpretation and analysis of Financial Statements, analysis of mark-ups, agreements, royalties, loans; selection of benchmarks; affidavits, reports, memos and audit reports are elaborated.

experience.position: Analyst | International Tax and Transaction Services | Transfer Pricing

education.schoolName: Pontificia Universidad Católica Argentina 'Santa María de los Buenos Aires'​

education.description:
- Implementation of Structured Query Language (SQL); 
- Design and development of dashboards with Power BI, using Data Analysis Expressions (DAX), M Language and Power Query.

receivedRecommendations.givenByHeadline: Gestora de proyectos y consultora multilingüe | Eficiencia operativa | Inclusión y relaciones internacionales | Transformación digital
receivedRecommendations.givenAt: October 13, 2023, María Agustina was senior to María Elena but didn't manage María Elena directly
receivedRecommendations.description:
It was a great pleasure to have had the opportunity to work with Maria in many projects at JPM. She is not only a Role Model but an excellent leader. She has shown to work with honesty and transparency, always well-organised, selfless and inclusive, also she was always committed to help others and teach. These are only a some of the qualities from a large list I can assure Maria has demonstrated to possess; and that she will take with her wherever her new adventures lead her. 
Dear Maru, wish you the very best, because you deserve it, you will be very much missed and I won’t forget what an honour was to work with you. Thank you and see you soon ✨

headline: Lead QA Engineer
about:
Globally distributed remote working is the ecosystem we face after the pandemic. 
Soft skills with high technicals knowledge became a must to manage teams properly. 

I am passionate about systems and information. 
Focused on detail, I pursue quality in every software I work in. 
How? With automation, the skill we need for testing consistently in a CICD process. 
I have more than 10 years of experience, working as an automation engineer, architect and leader. 

Continuously learning new technologies, management and leadership abilities. 
Motivated supportive leader, working with distributed teams in 4 different countries across Europe and India. 

Quality is a mindset, and through technology, we can do the impossible.

experience.description:
Technologies:

Automation:
Page object model and screenplay design patterns. 
Cucumber
Serenity
Selenium
Kafka
Selenoid
Jenkins
Maven
Gradle
Java

Systems:

Chatbot/digital assistance software based on artificial intelligence engine (Cognigy). Kafka based application programmed in Java. 

Salesforce based application for handling pre/post sales cases, used by call centers globally.

Setting up the Quality Engineering area in a Cybersecurity company
- Deciding the tools and technologies to be implemented for the automation strategy.
- Creation of the automation testing framework from scratch using Cucumber v6, Selenium using JAVA (WebDriver 3 and Grid 4), Jmeter, Jenkins and Docker.
- Jenkins: set up using Unix virtualized environments, node controller and agents, using Docker containers. Creations of the pipelines to orchestrate the automation scripts into the CICD process. 
- Docker: creation of Dockerfiles to generate the environments to support Jenkins agents capable of running Selenium and Jmeter test cases.
- Creation of the test strategy for the products of the company
- Raise awareness of what is quality and how to improve the development process from a QA perspective
- Automate functional test cases using Cucumber and Selenium, using a BDD approach. 
- Automate performance test cases using Jmeter
- Test API using SoapUI and restAssured. 
- SCRUM methodology
- Support the development team on testing tasks
- Support the management taking decisions related to quality improvement
- Report defects to achieve high quality products

Quality Engineer in a penetration testing application used for security information assessment (Impact)
Automation of TCs in Baco (proprietary, based on Pythton and XML)
Manual testing (bug tracking in TestLink)
Test plan creation (Tool TestLink)
Test Cases creation (tool TestLink)
Regression testing (tool Jenkins)
Learning complex scenarios in order to test new features related the penetration testing
Setting up complex multiple virtual machines environments (Unix, Windows, Fedora, Solaris, Free BSD)
Exploitation of vulnerabilities 
Information gathering
Network attack vectors
Client-side attack vectors
Web attack vectors
Wifi attack vectors
Mobile exploitation

Language: Python + XML

Functional testing.
Automated testing.
Scrum.
Creation of TCs based on BRD, Funcional specifications and UCs.
Daily scrum meetings with foreign leaders and developers.
Twice a week meetings with Bussiness Analyst team.

Automation Tools: Visual Studio + Team foundations server (TFS) + Fiddler
Language: .Net (C#)
Regression testing automation of Pagomiscuentas.com and several bank tools.

Complete testing course about good practices at testing standards, theorical and practical workshops. 
Creation of Test Cases and automated tests based on the tools developed by the company.

education.degree: Ingeniero en sistemas de la información

receivedRecommendations.givenByHeadline: Quality Engineering team lead
receivedRecommendations.givenAt: August 26, 2024, Roshni reported directly to Pablo
receivedRecommendations.description: A very good leader and mentor ever met in my career, great knowledgeable person with lot of automation talent and hardworking.

receivedRecommendations.givenByHeadline: QA Tester en Dimática
receivedRecommendations.givenAt: April 4, 2023, Sofia reported directly to Pablo
receivedRecommendations.description: Pablo es un gran Lead. Siempre disponible para guiar al equipo en todo lo que necesite y organizar el trabajo acorde a cada uno. Un placer siempre trabajar con él.

receivedRecommendations.givenByHeadline: Experienced SDET  | Gen AI Tech Professional | AEM  |Agentic AI & LLM Enthusiast |Driving Quality Excellence through Automation & Innovation
receivedRecommendations.givenAt: December 12, 2022, Nipun worked with Pablo on the same team
receivedRecommendations.description:
Pablo is a hardworking and dedicated resource who always keep a vision to push the things beyond limit .
i have worked with Pablo in a project and he is a gem in framework development and has outstanding testing skills.
Top of all he always lend helping hands to all the colleagues who so ever needs any technical help.He has started many new processes like preparing the documents for the new comers so that those documents can act as boon for their learning and trouble shooting the issues .

Would love to work with him in future also .

receivedRecommendations.givenByHeadline: Big Data Engineer | PySpark, SQL, Snowflake | AWS (S3, EMR, Glue, Redshift) | ETL Automation Developer | Airflow, Jenkins, Docker | Chatbot Dev: Amazon Lex, Connect, Cognigy AI
receivedRecommendations.givenAt: November 21, 2022, satarupa worked with Pablo but they were at different companies
receivedRecommendations.description:
Pablo and I worked on the same project.He is a good QA leader and helped me in execution of automation testing for the project.
it will be great pleasure to work under his mentorship again.

receivedRecommendations.givenByHeadline: Senior Business Analyst at Ping Identity
receivedRecommendations.givenAt: December 10, 2012, Deanne worked with Pablo but on different teams
receivedRecommendations.description: I worked closely with Pablo during the testing phase of multiple projects.  Pablo was always receptive to feedback and this was reflected in his willingness to expand upon and improve his test cases.  Pablo was thorough in his quality assurance efforts, demonstrating a desire to ensure that the finished product was of the highest quality.

receivedRecommendations.givenByHeadline: Lead IT Applications at Prologis
receivedRecommendations.givenAt: August 7, 2012, Victoria worked with Pablo on the same team
receivedRecommendations.description:
Pablo is an asset to any team and I was so glad he was a part of my team!  He is very detailed in providing sound test cases for the various projects assigned to our team.  He is always willing to take on what is needed to get the task completed and to make sure the project is a qualtiy product.

I always knew if Pablo was testing, bugs/defects were sure to be found, and I had the confidence that what we delievered was top notch!  Since working with Pablo, our final products rarely, if any, had issues in Production - I wish more testers were as complete as him!

receivedRecommendations.givenByHeadline: Senior Software Architect at Prosegur
receivedRecommendations.givenAt: May 16, 2012, Marcelo worked with Pablo on the same team
receivedRecommendations.description:
Pablo is a very thorough tester, he's always focused on excelence and he cares about the quality of the product.
He's also always looking for ways to improve his work and to make it more and more professional.

experience.position: Member of the Growing Finance & Infrastructure Group at B20
experience.description: Member of the B20 growing finance & infrastructure

A private equity investment fund targeted to the small/medium-cap private equity market whose differentiating thesis was to add value through management and operating expertise.

Strategy, Vision and Mission Planning:
Served as an operating member of deal teams in providing operating perspective and assessment of management, business plans, management process, and value.
Functioned as a Board member for a range of portfolio companies in the financial services sectors.
Overhaul senior leadership and initiated a formalized strategic planning process to establish core values and brand promise.
Assumed full responsibility in managing post-acquisition value-add which include strategic planning implementation, operational issues, and acquisition assessment.
Created financial brand strategy resulting in high IRR for investors.

•	Startup Sailing Global Investments – Brokerage, Sales and Trading (Alyc Nª 578)
•	Startup domestic and international financial businesses 
•	Relationship and networking with banks, financial institutions, investors and clients
•	Proven track record in advising clients on financial strategies (wealth and cash management)
•	Develop strategies with futures, options and swaps (FX)
•	Startup of new FinTech platform 
•	Understanding the needs and objectives and organizing a first class work team

•	Responsible for the international restructuring legal and debt program (IPO initial public offering 2011 with Barclays – N. York and London)
•	Responsible for definition, implementation and development of financial opportunities and businesses of the economic group, including local and international M&A 
•	Fully responsible for liquidity risk management, cash management, corporate finance, foreign exchange hedging and capital structure
•	Start up Hotel Casino Carrasco Uruguay

•	Debt restructuring process from default to more than 43 lines of credit
•	Identification and assessment of new businesses and opportunities 
•	M&A (spin-off, mergers, buy outs) strategic and coordination (implemented with Marval O´Farrell)
•	Supervision and coordination of interdisciplinary teams and Auditors
•	Member of Telefonica Group audit team. Financial statements auditing, internal audit, financial planning assessment and impairment analysis
•	Companies audited: Telefonica Group (Movistar, Unifon, Telefonica Moviles Argentina, Miniphone, Televisión Federal – TELEFE)

•	Prepared information memoranda, data rooms and business plans
•	Financial Statements analyst

experience.position: IBM Finance & Planning - Americas Expenses First Line Leader
Finance & Planning - GTS SSA PI Services - First Line Leader
experience.description: People Manager & Servant leader de 2 squads virtuales, llevando adelante la transformación e implementación Agile en GTS SSA Finanzas PI, lo que implica la automatización y simplificación de los principales procesos operativos y de gestion en el planning financiero, para el soporte de CFO y Ejecutivos de Negocio. También formo parte del desarrollo de iniciativas Ágiles junto con otros líderes globales, que replicarán eficiencia en todas las regiones del mundo. Educación sobre F&P y sobre practicas Agiles asi como armado y liderazgo de dinámicas grupales/fortalecimiento del equipo. Acompañamiento y desarrollo de estrategia para la interrelación de los nuevos squads para el soporte reciproco con otros squads/sectores de la organización. Actividades relacionadas al desarrollo de talentos en nuestra organizacion.

People Manager. Soporte, reporte y exposición de resultados, así como Business Insights al team Ejecutivo TSS SSA, GTS SSA, TSS LA, y SSA IBM (Line Exec & CFOs). Acompañamiento y consultoría a la línea de negocio para el desarrollo y crecimiento del negocio de TSS en SSA, obteniendo los mejores resultados bajo una adecuada postura de control. Asistir al negocio de TSS durante la transformación hacia MVS y el desarrollo de los nuevos Offerings de SW. Liderazgo de cadencias y transformacion de control de gestion en el planeamiento financiero. Desarrollo de Talento en nuestro equipo de trabajo, Educacion.
Consolidacion & Reporte de Estados de Resultados / Coordinacion y Consolidacion de Budget & Plan / Growth Iniciatives Analyst / Soporte Regional a CFO's y General Managers

experience.position: GTS SSA Finance & Planning - Education & Transformation Leader
experience.location: Buenos Aires, Provincia de Buenos Aires, Argentina
experience.description: Focal de Educación y transformación de procesos para el sector de finanzas y planeamiento dentro del segmento de Servicios en IBM Sudamérica. Reportando directamente al CFO regional de la Brand. Desarrollo e implementación del programa “Fast Start” para nuevos integrantes del sector (otorgándoles los primeros conocimientos de la función así como facilitarles las herramientas necesarias para iniciarse en sus posiciones); detección, desarrollo y facilitado de cursos para el fortalecimiento de skills y best practices del sector (viajando por sudamerica dando seminarios); diagnostico, desarrollo e implementación de nuevas practicas o procesos operativos para la mejora continua de la función de F&P. Dictado de cursos sobre planeamiento para la población general de empleados de IBM.

experience.position: GTS SSA Finance & Planning - Team Leader

receivedRecommendations.givenByHeadline: Global Offering Manager in IBM
receivedRecommendations.givenAt: April 3, 2025, Giselle was senior to Yesica Eliana but didn't manage Yesica Eliana directly
receivedRecommendations.description:
Trabaje con Yesica varios años,  siendo ella la Lider de Finazas para mi unidad de negocio, estando yo en un rol de COO .  
Yesica es una profestional excelente, cumplidora y comprometida.  Posee una gran capacidad para entender y apoyar las necesidades de negocio sin perder nunca el foco en el control financiero, lo que la posiciona como el partner ideal que cualquier Gte. de operaciones quisiera tener.  A su vez tiene un perfil de gran  liderazo  y alta calidad humana, lo que le permite manejar equipos con un gran sentido de pertenencia (incluso estando remoto).

receivedRecommendations.givenByHeadline: MBA | Corporate Finance | Planning | Non-Labor Lead for Strategic Markets at Kyndryl
receivedRecommendations.givenAt: March 24, 2025, Sergio reported directly to Yesica Eliana
receivedRecommendations.description: Tuve la oportunidad de trabajar con Yesica en IBM, especificamente en Finance & Planning de TSS, y puedo decir que es una profesional excepcional. Su profundo conocimiento, su disposición para apoyar activamente, y su actitud positiva (incluso en situaciones desafiantes), hicieron una gran diferencia en el equipo. Siempre fomentaba el empoderamiento, la delegación y la proactividad entre los miembros de su equipo, asegurando el desarrollo tanto personal como profesional de todos nosotros. Recomiendo a Yesica sin dudas como una líder inspiradora y estratégica.

receivedRecommendations.givenByHeadline: Kyndryl CFO LASW Latin America South West
receivedRecommendations.givenAt: November 12, 2023, Andrea managed Yesica Eliana directly
receivedRecommendations.description: I had opportunity to work with Yesi, in IBM, during almost 6 years.Yesi is very commit an responsable with results and engage her team to stay motivated. Yesi is very supportive and working to move transformation. It was a pleasure to work with Yesi.

receivedRecommendations.givenByHeadline: Global Offering Manager in IBM
receivedRecommendations.givenAt: April 3, 2025, Giselle was senior to Yesica Eliana but didn't manage Yesica Eliana directly
receivedRecommendations.description:
Trabaje con Yesica varios años,  siendo ella la Lider de Finazas para mi unidad de negocio, estando yo en un rol de COO .  
Yesica es una profestional excelente, cumplidora y comprometida.  Posee una gran capacidad para entender y apoyar las necesidades de negocio sin perder nunca el foco en el control financiero, lo que la posiciona como el partner ideal que cualquier Gte. de operaciones quisiera tener.  A su vez tiene un perfil de gran  liderazo  y alta calidad humana, lo que le permite manejar equipos con un gran sentido de pertenencia (incluso estando remoto).

receivedRecommendations.givenByHeadline: MBA | Corporate Finance | Planning | Non-Labor Lead for Strategic Markets at Kyndryl
receivedRecommendations.givenAt: March 24, 2025, Sergio reported directly to Yesica Eliana
receivedRecommendations.description: Tuve la oportunidad de trabajar con Yesica en IBM, especificamente en Finance & Planning de TSS, y puedo decir que es una profesional excepcional. Su profundo conocimiento, su disposición para apoyar activamente, y su actitud positiva (incluso en situaciones desafiantes), hicieron una gran diferencia en el equipo. Siempre fomentaba el empoderamiento, la delegación y la proactividad entre los miembros de su equipo, asegurando el desarrollo tanto personal como profesional de todos nosotros. Recomiendo a Yesica sin dudas como una líder inspiradora y estratégica.

receivedRecommendations.givenByHeadline: Kyndryl CFO LASW Latin America South West
receivedRecommendations.givenAt: November 12, 2023, Andrea managed Yesica Eliana directly
receivedRecommendations.description: I had opportunity to work with Yesi, in IBM, during almost 6 years.Yesi is very commit an responsable with results and engage her team to stay motivated. Yesi is very supportive and working to move transformation. It was a pleasure to work with Yesi.

headline: Product Manager | Diseño Industrial | Desarrollo de Producto
about:
Me considero una persona con habilidades para trabajar de manera autónoma y proactiva. Me siento cómoda aprendiendo y asimilando nuevos conocimientos.
Creo en la importancia de la perseverancia, el compromiso y la pasión para un buen desempeño laboral. Disfruto trabajando en equipo y considero que la retroalimentación entre pares es esencial para el crecimiento y el desarrollo de cualquier proyecto.

experience.location: Valencia/València, Comunidad Valenciana / Comunitat Valenciana, España
experience.description:
•	Gestión integral de productos de la categoría GAE cocina, abarcando desde la investigación de mercado hasta su lanzamiento.
	•	Análisis de comportamiento del consumidor y procesamiento de datos para la toma de decisiones estratégicas.
	•	Búsqueda, evaluación y gestión de proveedores internacionales.
	•	Desarrollo de productos a lo largo de todo su ciclo de vida: diseño, producción, testeo y negociación.
	•	Solicitud y validación de muestras, seguimiento de procesos de diseño e industrialización.
	•	Coordinación de lanzamientos de producto y supervisión de materiales de comunicación: manuales, artworks, fichas técnicas, catálogos generales y de gama.
	•	Participación activa en ferias internacionales como Canton Fair (ediciones 135/136/137) en China e IFA 2024 en Berlín.

•	Investigación de tendencias de diseño aplicadas a nuevos productos.
	•	Evaluación del estado de productos considerando su ciclo de vida para toma de decisiones estratégicas.
	•	Análisis de packaging orientado a optimización de presentación y funcionalidad.
	•	Estudio de posicionamiento de precios en el mercado y propuestas de ajuste competitivo.
	•	Benchmarking de productos frente a la competencia en términos de diseño, precio y funcionalidad.
	•	Gestión de altas y bajas de productos, incluyendo desarrollo de fichas técnicas y especificaciones.
	•	Revisión y actualización de catálogos de productos.
	•	Creación de manuales e instructivos de uso orientados a cliente final y equipo interno.

•	Diseño y desarrollo técnico de expositores para distintos tipos de productos, adaptados a distintos procesos  de fabricación.
	•	Elaboración de planos técnicos y modelado 3D de piezas y conjuntos.
	•	Optimización de recursos productivos, garantizando eficiencia en tiempos y costos de producción.
	•	Control y gestión eficiente de materiales, asegurando el cumplimiento de los costos asignados para cada proyecto.

•	Diseño y elaboración de planos técnicos de mobiliario urbano y sistemas de cartelería.
	•	Preparación de archivos CNC para equipos de Router y Punzonadora.
	•	Gestión de stock de materiales y realización de pedidos para obras y proyectos.
	•	Seguimiento de la producción para asegurar la calidad, plazos de entrega y correcta ejecución de los proyectos.

education.fieldOfStudy: Diseño cerámico. Moldes y modelado en CNC.

receivedRecommendations.givenByHeadline: Industrial Designer
receivedRecommendations.givenAt: May 3, 2023, Hernan managed Karina Elizabeth directly
receivedRecommendations.description:
Tuve el agrado de tener a Kari en mi equipo de desarrollo de producto en LibsonGroup. 
Ella es una persona alegre, detallista, y con gran habilidad para resolver los problemas que se le presentan.
Sabe aplicar sus conocimientos técnicos, se desenvuelve muy bien en el uso de modelado cad 3D, y en la gestión de documentación técnica, y es muy ordenada.
También es muy buena en su forma de trabajar con los grupos de trabajo dentro de la empresa , los proovedores y los clientes.
Tenerla en su equipo de trabajo será muy beneficioso!


I was pleased to have Karina on my product development team at LibsonGroup.
She has the ability to solve any problems that may arise. She is a cheerful, thoughtful and easy going.
She knows how to apply her technical knowledge. She has excelent 3D CAD modeling skills and technical documentation. Her ability in work groups is outstanding and also her relations with clients and customers. 
Having her on your team will nothing but exceptional.

receivedRecommendations.givenByHeadline: Sales Manager at Oakley Argentina
receivedRecommendations.givenAt: April 27, 2023, Maria Paula worked with Karina Elizabeth but on different teams
receivedRecommendations.description:
Karina es una gran profesional, eficiente y predispuesta. Proactiva en su tarea y atenta a cumplir con los desafíos propuestos. 
Una líder natural de proyectos plurales y gran integradora de equipos de trabajo. 

Destaco su capacidad resolutiva, tenacidad y compromiso diario; pero por sobre todo resalto su calidad humana, valores y agradable trato.

receivedRecommendations.givenByHeadline: Diseñadora Industrial
receivedRecommendations.givenAt: April 24, 2023, Daniela worked with Karina Elizabeth on the same team
receivedRecommendations.description:
Karina es una excelente diseñadora industrial, con grandes aptitudes para el diseño y desarrollo técnico de productos y su respectiva documentación. 
Destaco su organización ante cada nuevo desarrollo su capacidad de adaptación y su perfil multitasking. 
Eficiente, sabe liderar grupos de trabajo, siempre con predisposición y gran compromiso laboral.
